#Text=THE NEST OF THE MISSEL THRUSH

#Text=For two or three minutes he stood looking round him , while Mary watched him , and then he began to walk about softly , even more lightly than Mary had walked the first time she had found herself inside the four walls .

#Text=His eyes seemed to be taking in everything — the gray trees with the gray creepers climbing over them and hanging from their branches , the tangle on the walls and among the grass , the evergreen alcoves with the stone seats and tall flower urns standing in them .
#Text=“ I never thought I ’d see this place , ” he said at last , in a whisper .
#Text=“ Did you know about it ? ” asked Mary .
#Text=She had spoken aloud and he made a sign to her .
#Text=“ We must talk low , ” he said , “ or someone ’ll hear us an ’ wonder what ’s to do in here . ”
#Text=“ Oh ! I forgot ! ” said Mary , feeling frightened and putting her hand quickly against her mouth .
#Text=“ Did you know about the garden ? ” she asked again when she had recovered herself .
#Text=Dickon nodded .
#Text=“ Martha told me there was one as no one ever went inside , ” he answered .
#Text=“ Us used to wonder what it was like . ”
#Text=He stopped and looked round at the lovely gray tangle about him , and his round eyes looked queerly happy .
#Text=“ Eh ! the nests as ’ll be here come springtime , ” he said .
#Text=“ It ’d be th ’ safest nestin ’ place in England .
#Text=No one never comin ’ near an ’ tangles o ’ trees an ’ roses to build in .
#Text=I wonder all th ’ birds on th ’ moor do n’t build here . ”
#Text=Mistress
#Text=Mary put her hand on his arm again without knowing it .
#Text=“ Will there be roses ? ” she whispered .
#Text=“ Can you tell ?
#Text=I thought perhaps they were all dead . ”
#Text=“ Eh ! No ! Not them — not all of ’ em ! ” he answered .
#Text=“ Look here ! ”
#Text=He stepped over to the nearest tree — an old , old one with gray lichen all over its bark , but upholding a curtain of tangled sprays and branches .
#Text=He took a thick knife out of his pocket and opened one of its blades .
#Text=“ There ’s lots o ’ dead wood as ought to be cut out , ” he said .
#Text=“ An ’ there ’s a lot o ’ old wood , but it made some new last year .
#Text=This here ’s a new bit , ” and he touched a shoot which looked brownish green instead of hard , dry gray .
#Text=Mary touched it herself in an eager , reverent way .
#Text=“ That one ? ” she said .
#Text=“ Is that one quite alive quite ? ”
#Text=Dickon curved his wide smiling mouth .
#Text=“ It ’s as wick as you or me , ” he said ; and Mary remembered that Martha had told her that “ wick ” meant “ alive ” or “ lively . ”
#Text=“ I ’m glad it ’s wick ! ” she cried out in her whisper .
#Text=“ I want them all to be wick .
#Text=Let us go round the garden and count how many wick ones there are . ”
#Text=She quite panted with eagerness , and Dickon was as eager as she was .
#Text=They went from tree to tree and from bush to bush .
#Text=Dickon carried his knife in his hand and showed her things which she thought wonderful .
#Text=“ They ’ve run wild , ” he said , “ but th ’ strongest ones has fair thrived on it .
#Text=The delicatest ones has died out , but th ’ others has growed an ’ growed , an ’ spread an ’ spread , till they ’s a wonder .
#Text=See here ! ” and he pulled down a thick gray , dry-looking branch .
#Text=“ A body might think this was dead wood , but I do n’t believe it is — down to th ’ root .
#Text=I ’ll cut it low down an ’ see . ”
#Text=He knelt and with his knife cut the lifeless-looking branch through , not far above the earth .
#Text=“ There ! ” he said exultantly . “ I told thee so .
#Text=There ’s green in that wood yet .
#Text=Look at it . ”
#Text=Mary was down on her knees before he spoke , gazing with all her might .
#Text=“ When it looks a bit greenish an ’ juicy like that , it ’s wick , ” he explained .
#Text=“ When th ’ inside is dry an ’ breaks easy , like this here piece I ’ve cut off , it ’s done for .

#Text=There ’s a big root here as all this live wood sprung out of , an ’ if th ’ old wood ’s cut off an ’ it ’s dug round , and took care of there ’ll be — ” he stopped and lifted his face to look up at the climbing and hanging sprays above him — “ there ’ll be a fountain o ’ roses here this summer . ”
#Text=They went from bush to bush and from tree to tree .
#Text=He was very strong and clever with his knife and knew how to cut the dry and dead wood away , and could tell when an unpromising bough or twig had still green life in it .

#Text=In the course of half an hour Mary thought she could tell too , and when he cut through a lifeless-looking branch she would cry out joyfully under her breath when she caught sight of the least shade of moist green .
#Text=The spade , and hoe , and fork were very useful .
#Text=He showed her how to use the fork while he dug about roots with the spade and stirred the earth and let the air in .
#Text=They were working industriously round one of the biggest standard roses when he caught sight of something which made him utter an exclamation of surprise .
#Text=“ Why ! ” he cried , pointing to the grass a few feet away .
#Text=“ Who did that there ? ”
#Text=It was one of Mary ’s own little clearings round the pale green points .
#Text=“ I did it , ” said Mary .
#Text=“ Why , I thought tha ’ did n’t know nothin ’ about gardenin ’ , ” he exclaimed .
